metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Revashankar

facts.text: Ganga Ram instituted suit No. 1383 of 1952 in court of Additional City Civil Judge, Indore, for ejectment and arrears of rent against Revashankar.
Uma Shankar Chaturvedi advised Ganga Ram to sign name of his wife Chandra Mukhi Bai on plaint and vakalatnama, though she did not sign.
Chandra Mukhi Bai filed application for permission to prosecute her husband for forgery. Other tenants filed application with allegations against Revashankar.

On June 29, 1953, Revashankar filed complaint under s.500 IPC against five persons, verified July 13, 1953, registered as Criminal Case No. 637 of 1953 before Additional District Magistrate N.K. Acharya, Indore.
Kulkarni appeared for complainant Revashankar; accused appeared through Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar Chaturvedi on August 8, 1953. Objection to Kulkarni's appearance as he was witness.
On October 12, 1953, Magistrate ordered copies of applications and affidavits sent to District Judge for action against lawyers.
Criminal case No. 644 of 1953 against Revashankar under s.497 IPC started on complaint of Ganga Ram before Additional City Magistrate Circle No.2.

On December 17, 1953, Revashankar filed application under s.528 CrPC in court of Additional District Magistrate N.K. Acharya in Criminal Case No. 637/1953, containing aspersions: (1) Magistrate favouring Uma Shankar Chaturvedi; (2) no impartial justice; (3) Magistrate conspired with Mohan Singh and Uma Shankar re ornaments of Chandra Mukhi Bai to implicate Revashankar and brother in theft; (4) Uma Shankar paid Rs.500 bribe to Magistrate via Ganga Ram.
Aspersions repeated in affidavit dated December 21, 1953.
On January 11, 1954, Magistrate reported to Registrar, Madhya Bharat High Court, praying action against Revashankar for contempt.
High Court issued notice to Revashankar; Criminal Miscellaneous Application No. 2 of 1954 started.
High Court (Newaskar and Samvatsar JJ.) by order February 9, 1955, held jurisdiction ousted under s.32 Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 as act constituted offence under s.228 IPC.
Appeal by special leave filed by State of Madhya Bharat (substituted by State of Madhya Pradesh).

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances the High Court was correct in holding that the act of the respondent constituted an offence under s.228 IPC, ousting jurisdiction under s.32 Contempt of Courts Act, 1952.

petitioner_arguments.text: Allegations in transfer application and affidavit are serious, scandalise the Court, create distrust in public mind, pollute stream of justice; not mere personal insult.
No intention to insult under s.228 IPC; primary object was transfer, not insult.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Narotam Das v. Emperor AIR 1943 All 97; earlier Allahabad cases

petitioner_arguments.text: Where allegations go beyond personal insult to bring administration of justice into disrepute, High Court jurisdiction not ousted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: L.R. 1941 Nagpur 304; Emperor v. Jagnath Prasad Swadhiry L.R. 1938 All 548; I.L.R. 12 Patna 1; I.L.R. 12 Patna 172

petitioner_arguments.text: Doubts whether intention to insult, whether insult offered, whether during stage of judicial proceeding; if any essential lacking, no s.228 offence.

respondent_arguments.text: Act intentionally offers personal insult to Magistrate, constitutes offence under s.228 IPC, ousts High Court jurisdiction under s.32 Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: 1952 SCR 425; 1953 SCR 1169; s.32 Contempt of Courts Act; s.228 IPC; s.480 CrPC; 1922 ILR 46 Bom 973

respondent_arguments.text: Every insult to Court, whatever nature, is contempt punishable under s.228 IPC.

court_reasoning.text: s.32 Act excludes High Court jurisdiction only where contempt is offence punishable as contempt under specific IPC provisions (ss.175,178,179,180,228), not other offences.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bathina Ramakrishna Reddy v. State of Madras (1952 SCR 425)

court_reasoning.text: Object of contempt is to protect public confidence in administration of justice, not judges personally; scandalising court creates distrust.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Brahma Prakash Sharma v. State of UP (1953 SCR 1169)

court_reasoning.text: Unclear if Magistrate sitting in stage of judicial proceeding when application/affidavit filed; if not, no s.228 offence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.228 IPC requires public servant sitting in judicial proceeding

court_reasoning.text: Aspersions prima facie more than mere insult: scandalise court (conspiracy to implicate in false theft, bribe of Rs.500), create distrust.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Taken at face value, attack on court impairs confidence

court_reasoning.text: Intention to insult depends on facts; no hard rule that transfer applications with defamatory assertions lack intention to insult.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Narotam Das incorrectly relied on by High Court

court_reasoning.text: True test: if act scandalises court rather than mere insult, High Court jurisdiction not ousted.

holdings.text: High Court jurisdiction under Contempt of Courts Act not ousted by s.32 as act is more than s.228 IPC offence; scandalises court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bathina Ramakrishna Reddy v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Interprets s.23 Contempt Act 1926 (similar to s.32 1952 Act): excludes jurisdiction only if contempt punishable as such under specific IPC provisions

precedents_cited.case_name: Brahma Prakash Sharma v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of contempt: protect public confidence in courts; scandalising court impairs administration of justice
High Court relied on it for no intention to insult in transfer applications; SC holds tests not determinative
High Court jurisdiction not ousted by s.228 in scandalous communications
No intention to insult in transfer application with defamatory assertions
No intention to insult in transfer application with defamatory assertions

precedents_cited.case_name: Ambard v. Attorney-General for Trinidad and Tobago
precedents_cited.relevance: Criticism allowed if not imputing improper motives or impairing justice

statutes_cited.name: Contempt of Courts Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: s.32 ousts High Court jurisdiction only if contempt is offence punishable as contempt under IPC; s.4 punishment for contempt

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: s.228: intentional insult to public servant in judicial proceeding; determines if jurisdiction ousted

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: s.528: transfer application; s.480: courts punish for certain IPC contempts including s.228

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order dated February 9, 1955 set aside; High Court to take cognizance and decide case on merits in accordance with law.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court jurisdiction affirmed; matter remitted for decision on merits

key_quotes.text: "the sub-section referred to above excludes the jurisdiction of High Court only in cases where the acts alleged to constitute contempt of a subordinate court are punishable as contempt under specific provisions of the Indian Penal Code"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation of s.32 Contempt Act from Ramakrishna Reddy

key_quotes.text: "It would be only repeating what has been said so often... that the object of contempt proceedings is not to afford protection to Judges personally... but... protection to the public whose interests would be very much affected if... the authority of the court is lowered"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core purpose of contempt from Brahma Prakash Sharma

key_quotes.text: "the aspersions made therein prima facie showed that they were much more than a mere insult to the learned Magistrate in effect, they scandalised the Court in such a way as to create distrust in the popular mind"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Why s.228 not attracted; jurisdiction not ousted
